   CT ABDOMEN
   1. Extensive fluid collections identified in the abdomen and pelvis,
   most of
   which are stable in size. Percutaneous drains remain in situ within one
   of
   these along the right. A new fluid collection is seen adjacent to the
   pancreatic tail extending along small bowel loops to the left abdominal
   flank.
   2. New areas of consolidation and ground-glass opacity are identified
   in the
   right middle lobe and right lower lobe consistent with pneumonia or
   aspiration.
   Assessment and Plan
   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatinine started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%.  Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - UOP improved today on lasix, but Cr still rising, worsening
   hyponatremia
   - monitor lytes [**Hospital1 **]; trend Cr
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
 reconfirm
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT (goals of care)
   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Unresponsiveness S/p PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No
   hypoglycemia on the scene, and no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  Cardiac
   enzymes and CTA chest were negative.  The patient was noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Still unresponsive after
   discontinuation of midazolam for sedation.  DDx includes sedation
   (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e. stroke),
   seizure, metabolic (i.e. hyponatremia).
   - f/u EEG resuls to r/o epileptiform activity
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .
   # aspiration +/- PNA
 as seen on CT chest
   - continue intubation and wean as tolerated
   - currently on Zosyn
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections: On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling
   defect, suggestive of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS
   which revealed a large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also
   performed, which confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted
   multiple large abdominal fluid collections. He was evaluated by general
   surgery, who thought his abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and
   associated inflammation was relatively immature, and that surgical
   intervention or drainage at this time was not indicated. They
   recommended that the patient continue to be NPO, continue nutrition
   with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks with repeat imaging and
   clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical intervention at that
   time.  Now s/p IR-guided embolization of GDA pseudoaneurysm, which
   appeared to have hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst.
    - was on meropenem; switched to Zosyn per ID recs as they felt that it
   could explain his abdominal rash
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - CT shows e/o new pseudocyst, may contribute to abdominal distention
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - trend Hct
   .
   # abdominal rash
 Continues to spread.  Thought to be drug-induced,
   with the most likely suspect being abx.  Both vancomycin and meropenem
   have been d/ced since development of rash.
   - continue to monitor
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   Now with worsening abdominal distention, although this could be from
   massive fluid overload.
   - cont vanc enemas + IV flagyl and cont for until has completed other
   antibiotics then for an additional 14d
   - transduce bladder pressure serially
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - amiodarone redosed to gtt given inability to administer PO meds;
   after 1 week will need to redose
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .
   # Family Contact
   Patient's family contact is the patient's niece [**Name (NI) 12548**] [**Name (NI) 12549**]. Her
   home number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12550**]; work number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12551**]; cell number
   is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12552**]..
   .

   MICU Attending Addendum:
   On this day I examined the patient and was present for the key portions
   of the services provided.  I have reviewed Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 12690**]
s note above
   and agree with his findings and plan of care.  Mr [**Known lastname 12624**] is a
   previously healthy elderly man with severe pancreatitis, psedocysts,
   pseudoanerysm, s/p PEA arrest with CPR for 25min, renal failure, resp
   failure, hypotension on pressors, severe ongoing leukocytosis, and
   obtundation despite our stopping sedatives.
   His obtundation is likely multifactorial. He did respond to commands
   shortly after being resuscitated, so I doubt anoxic encephalopathy
   explains it all. But this CNS insult, plus his age and renal failure
   and the SIRS state from pancreatitis may well be enough to keep him
   obtunded. His obtundation is contributing to his being on the vent
   still, as is his tense abdomen and acidosis and fluid overload.  His
   renal failure is likely from both his CP Arrest and pancreatitis.
   His prognosis is obviously not good, given the co-morbidities of great
   severity.  Goals of care are to be addressed by his neice who is his
   health care proxy, and another relative who is a physician. [**Name10 (NameIs) **] the
   desire is to continue
aggressive
 care, then he will need CNS imaging
   in addition to the EEG the results of which are pending. He will also
   need consideration of CVHD by renal in an effort to get off fluid,
   correct hyponatremia, and improve mental status.  His pseudocysts are
   very large and he remains on broad spectrum antibiotics. Surgery
   following and we
ll discuss with them if any intervention is in order,
   which I doubt.
   If, however, goals of care are desired by family to be directed toward
   comfort, we are prepared to move in that direction as well.
   50min spent in the care of this complex and critically ill patient.
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 712**], MD

   failure, hypotension on pressors, severe ongoing leukocytosis, and
   obtundation despite our stopping sedatives.
   His obtundation is likely multifactorial. He did respond to commands
   shortly after being resuscitated, so I doubt anoxic encephalopathy
   explains it all. But this CNS insult, plus his age and renal failure
   and the SIRS state from pancreatitis may well be enough to keep him
   obtunded. His obtundation is contributing to his being on the vent
   still, as is his tense abdomen and acidosis and fluid overload.  His
   renal failure is likely from both his CP Arrest and pancreatitis.
   His prognosis is obviously not good, given the co-morbidities of great

aggressive
 care, then he will need CNS imaging

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a complex medical history, including a large pancreatic pseudocyst, intra-abdominal fluid collections, and a GDA pseudoaneurysm that hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst. He has also experienced a PEA arrest, which required CPR for 25 minutes, and has developed acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and hypotension.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: intubated and mechanically ventilated
* Hemodynamic support: vasopressors and fluids
* Renal support: diuretics and consideration of CRRT
* Neurological status: obtunded and unresponsive
* Abdominal status: tense and distended, with multiple fluid collections and a new pseudocyst
* Laboratory results: abnormal electrolyte levels, including hyponatremia and hyperkalemia
* Imaging studies: extensive fluid collections in the abdomen and pelvis, with new areas of consolidation and ground-glass opacity in the right middle lobe and right lower lobe consistent with pneumonia or aspiration

Potential medical complications:

* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to pancreatitis and hypovolemia
* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia or aspiration
* Sepsis due to pancreatitis and intra-abdominal infections
* Hepatic failure due to pancreatitis and possible liver damage
* Cardiac arrhythmias due to electrolyte imbalances and pancreatitis
* Pneumonia or aspiration due to intubation and mechanical ventilation
* Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) due to antibiotic use
* Abdominal compartment syndrome due to tense and distended abdomen

Plan:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies
* Continue to provide respiratory and hemodynamic support as needed
* Consider CRRT for renal support
* Continue to manage abdominal distension and fluid collections
* Consider surgical intervention for abdominal compartment syndrome
* Monitor for signs of sepsis and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed
* Consider CVHD for renal support
* Monitor for signs of cardiac arrhythmias and adjust therapy as needed
* Consider CNS imaging and EEG to rule out seizures and structural defects
* Continue to communicate with the family and healthcare proxy regarding the patient's condition and goals of care.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatining started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%. Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - UOP improved today on lasix, but Cr still rising
   - monitor lytes [**Hospital1 **]; trend Cr
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT
   .
   # Unresponsiveness S/p PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No
   hypoglycemia on the scene, and no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  EKG w/o
   evidence of ACS, cardiac markers pending.  the patient was noted to be
   tachypneic, so should consider PE.  No right heart strain on EKG.  The
   patient was noted noted to be hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must
   also consider more active bleed from pseudoaneurysm.  Potential for
   aspiration as precipitating event as well.  TTE, LENIs, CTA neg.
   - continue intubation for airway protection and wean as tolerated
   - avoiding BZDs today, continue fentanyl
   - IVF, wean pressors as tolerated
   - trend Hct for e/o of active bleed ([**Hospital1 **])
   .
   # AMS
 Still unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for
   sedation.  Rhythmic motion of R leg concerning for seizure. Worried
   that prior BZDs were masking seizure.
   - f/u EEG resuls to r/o epileptiform activity
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .
   # aspiration +/- PNA
 as seen on CT chest
   - currently on Zosyn
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections:
   On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling defect, suggestive
   of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS which revealed a
   large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also performed, which
   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation
   was relatively immature, and that surgical intervention or drainage at
   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue
   to be NPO, continue nutrition with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks
   with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical
   intervention at that time..
   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.
   Repeat imaging reveals interval progression.  Given hemorrhage into
   pseudocyst, may very well be reactive inflammation from hemorrhage.  CT
   did not reveal necrotic component.
   - was on meropenem; switched to Zosyn per ID recs as they felt that it
   could explain his abdominal rash
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - CT shows e/o new pseudocyst
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - Hct continues to drop; patient will go for IR-guided embolization of
   GDA pseudoaneurysm today
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   Now with worsening abdominal distention, although this could be from
   massive fluid overload.
   - cont vanc enemas + IV flagyl and cont for until has completed other
   antibiotics then for an additional 14d
   - transduce bladder pressure
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - amiodarone redosed to gtt given inability to administer PO meds
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.
   .
   # Family Contact
   Patient's family contact is the patient's niece [**Name (NI) 12548**] [**Name (NI) 12549**]. Her
   home number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12550**]; work number is ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 12551**]; cell number

   .

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine levels are rising, and he is at risk of developing ARF due to his history of pancreatitis, GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage, and potential nephrotoxic medications.
2. Aspiration Pneumonia (AP): The patient has a history of pancreatitis, which increases his risk of developing AP. The CT chest shows new areas of consolidation and ground-glass opacity, which may be consistent with pneumonia or aspiration.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has a history of pancreatitis, which can lead to pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, and potential complications such as hemorrhage, infection, and organ failure.
4. Clostridium difficile infection (CDI): The patient was diagnosed with CDI and is being treated with flagyl and vancomycin. However, his abdominal distention and diarrhea may be worsening, which could indicate a poor response to treatment.
5. Atrial Fibrillation (AF): The patient has a history of AF, which can increase his risk of developing cardiac complications such as heart failure, stroke, and arrhythmias.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, which may be due to pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis or a new diagnosis of diabetes.
7. Hepatic Cirrhosis: The patient's imaging studies show evidence of hepatic cirrhosis, although the hepatology team is uncertain about the diagnosis.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage, which can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and potential complications such as shock, organ failure, and death.
9. Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated, and his respiratory status is monitored closely. He is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to his underlying medical conditions and potential complications such as pneumonia or aspiration.
10. Sepsis: The patient has a history of pancreatitis, which can increase his risk of developing sepsis due to bacterial translocation from the gut to the bloodstream.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid and electrolyte management accordingly.
2. Continue to treat the patient's pancreatitis with antibiotics and supportive care.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilator settings as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding risk and adjust his anticoagulation therapy accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's blood glucose levels and adjust his insulin therapy accordingly.
6. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's hepatic cirrhosis, including liver biopsy and hepatology consultation.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's sepsis risk and adjust his antibiotic therapy accordingly.
8. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's atrial fibrillation, including cardioversion and anticoagulation therapy.

   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.

   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatinine started trending up in

   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%.  Worsening today,
   uptrending by 0.3 daily.
   - UOP improved today on lasix, but Cr still rising, worsening
   hyponatremia
   - monitor lytes [**Hospital1 **]; trend Cr
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
 reconfirm

   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Unresponsiveness S/p PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No
   hypoglycemia on the scene, and no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  Cardiac
   enzymes and CTA chest were negative.  The patient was noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Still unresponsive after
   discontinuation of midazolam for sedation.  DDx includes sedation
   (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e. stroke),
   seizure, metabolic (i.e. hyponatremia).
   - f/u EEG resuls to r/o epileptiform activity
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .

 as seen on CT chest
   - continue intubation and wean as tolerated
   - currently on Zosyn
   .

   Collections: On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling
   defect, suggestive of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS
   which revealed a large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also
   performed, which confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted
   multiple large abdominal fluid collections. He was evaluated by general
   surgery, who thought his abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and
   associated inflammation was relatively immature, and that surgical
   intervention or drainage at this time was not indicated. They
   recommended that the patient continue to be NPO, continue nutrition
   with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks with repeat imaging and
   clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical intervention at that
   time.  Now s/p IR-guided embolization of GDA pseudoaneurysm, which
   appeared to have hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst.
    - was on meropenem; switched to Zosyn per ID recs as they felt that it

   - ID recs

   - f/u general surgery recs

 Continues to spread.  Thought to be drug-induced,

   have been d/ced since development of rash.
   - continue to monitor

   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He was initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.

   massive fluid overload.
   - cont vanc enemas + IV flagyl and cont for until has completed other

   - transduce bladder pressure serially

   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained

   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more

   .

1. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine levels are rising, and he has been diagnosed with ARF. He is at risk of developing further kidney damage if not managed properly.
2. Unresponsiveness: The patient remains unresponsive, and the differential diagnosis includes sedation, uremia, structural defect (i.e., stroke), seizure, and metabolic (i.e., hyponatremia). Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
3. Aspiration/Pneumonia: The patient has a history of aspiration, and his CT chest shows new areas of consolidation and ground-glass opacity, consistent with pneumonia or aspiration.
4. Pancreatitis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal Fluid Collections: The patient has a large pancreatic pseudocyst and multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections, which can lead to further complications such as abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting.
5. Clostridium difficile infection (CDI): The patient has a history of CDI, which can lead to further complications such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and electrolyte imbalances.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which can lead to further complications such as heart failure, stroke, and arrhythmias.
7. Hepatic Cirrhosis: The patient has been diagnosed with hepatic cirrhosis, which can lead to further complications such as ascites, portal hypertension, and liver failure.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient has a history of hyperglycemia, which can lead to further complications such as ketoacidosis, coma, and long-term complications such as diabetic neuropathy and nephropathy.
9. Abdominal Rash: The patient has an abdominal rash, which may be related to antibiotic use or other medications.

The patient's current medications include amiodarone, furosemide (Lasix), norepinephrine, and pantoprazole (Protonix). He is also receiving TPN with lipids and has been started on insulin for glycemic control.

   patient was noted noted to be hypoxic leading up to the event.  Must

   confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted multiple large abdominal
   fluid collections. He was evaluated by general surgery, who thought his
   abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and associated inflammation

   this time was not indicated. They recommended that the patient continue

   Patient now with rising WBC, rising lipase, and increasing LUQ pain.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, and a GDA pseudoaneurysm that has hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst. He was transferred to the ICU from an outside hospital (OSH) for further evaluation and management.

The patient's current condition is marked by:

1. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): His creatinine has risen to 1.2, and he is oliguric. He was given one dose of lasix, which improved his urine output, but his creatinine continues to rise.
2. Unresponsiveness: The patient remains unresponsive after discontinuation of midazolam for sedation, and there is concern for seizure activity, including rhythmic motion of his right leg.
3. AMS: The patient is still unresponsive and has not been assessed for mental status since withdrawal of midazolam.
4. Aspiration/PNA: The patient has been diagnosed with pneumonia or aspiration, as evidenced by new areas of consolidation and ground-glass opacity on CT chest.
5. Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis, with a large pancreatic pseudocyst and multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections.
6. Intra-abdominal fluid collections: The patient has multiple fluid collections in the abdomen and pelvis, which are thought to be related to his pseudocyst.
7. GDA pseudoaneurysm: The patient has a GDA pseudoaneurysm that has hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst, which requires IR-guided embolization.
8. Clostridium difficile infection: The patient was diagnosed with C. diff infection and started on flagyl, but now has worsening abdominal distention.
9. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and is being treated with amiodarone.
10. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, which may be related to pancreatic insufficiency or a new diagnosis of diabetes.
11. Hepatic Cirrhosis: The patient has hepatic cirrhosis, although he has no prior history of it. The hepatology team is consulting to determine the cause of the ascites.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's multiple fluid collections, pancreatitis, and C. diff infection put him at risk for developing sepsis.
2. Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN): The patient's ARF and potential for nephrotoxic medications increase his risk for developing ATN.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's pneumonia or aspiration and potential for respiratory failure from his pancreatitis and intra-abdominal fluid collections require close monitoring.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and potential for cardiac arrhythmias require close monitoring and management.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and fluid collections increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
6. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of multiple catheters and lines increase his risk for developing infections.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his condition, including:

1. Monitoring his vital signs and laboratory values, including creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and electrolytes.
2. Managing his pain and sedation needs.
3. Providing nutrition and glycemic control through TPN and insulin.
4. Monitoring his fluid status and electrolyte balance.
5. Managing his atrial fibrillation and potential cardiac complications.
6. Monitoring for signs of sepsis and potential infections.
7. Considering the need for CRRT or other renal replacement therapy.
8. Consulting with the hepatology team to determine the cause of the patient's ascites and potential hepatic cirrhosis.

   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatinine started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%.  Worsening today,
   uptrending daily.
   - UOP improved today on lasix, but Cr still rising, worsening
   hyponatremia
   - monitor lytes [**Hospital1 **]; trend Cr
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
 reconfirm
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT (goals of care)
   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Unresponsiveness S/p PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No
   hypoglycemia on the scene, and no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  Cardiac
   enzymes and CTA chest were negative.  The patient was noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Still unresponsive after
   discontinuation of midazolam for sedation.  DDx includes sedation
   (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e. stroke),
   seizure, metabolic (i.e. hyponatremia).
   - f/u EEG resuls to r/o epileptiform activity --> prelim is
   encephalopathy
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .
   # Pancreatititis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, Intra-abdominal fluid
   Collections: On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling
   defect, suggestive of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS
   which revealed a large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also
   performed, which confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted
   multiple large abdominal fluid collections. He was evaluated by general
   surgery, who thought his abdominal process of pancreatic pseudocyst and
   associated inflammation was relatively immature, and that surgical
   intervention or drainage at this time was not indicated. They
   recommended that the patient continue to be NPO, continue nutrition
   with TPN, and then follow-up in [**5-6**] weeks with repeat imaging and
   clinic follow-up for consideration of surgical intervention at that
   time.  Now s/p IR-guided embolization of GDA pseudoaneurysm, which
   appeared to have hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst. Worsening leukocytosis
    - was on meropenem; switched to Zosyn per ID recs and later to
   Aztreonam/Cipro
   - ID recs
   - f/u pending blood and urine cultures.
   - CT shows e/o new pseudocyst, may contribute to abdominal distention
   - f/u general surgery recs
   - trend Hct
   .
   # aspiration +/- PNA
 as seen on CT chest
   - continue intubation and wean as tolerated
   - currently on Aztreonam/Cipro
   .
   # abdominal rash
 Continues to spread.  Thought to be drug-induced,
   with the most likely suspect being abx.  Both vancomycin and meropenem
   have been d/ced since development of rash.
   - continue to monitor
   .
   # Clostridium difficile infection:
   Within 48 hours of admission, patient developed increased diarrhea and
   marked leukocytosis from 17 to 26. He was C. diff positive and started
   on flagyl on [**2166-5-7**] with improvement in his diarrhea. He as initially
   stated on flagyl, but started on PO vanc on the day of ICU transfer.
   Now with worsening abdominal distention, although this could be from
   massive fluid overload.
   - cont vanc enemas + IV flagyl and cont for until has completed other
   antibiotics then for an additional 14d
   - transduce bladder pressure serially
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation
   Patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation at the OSH and was
   started on diltiazem before being transitioned to amiodarone. Upon
   transfer to [**Hospital1 5**], his PICC line was noted to be advanced into the
   right atrium, and it was thought that this may have been triggering his
   atrial fibrillation. During his hospitalization at [**Hospital1 5**], he remained
   in sinus rhythm and with excellent rate control. His chart says that
   his amioderone was discontinued, but currently ordered.
   - amiodarone redosed to gtt given inability to administer PO meds;
   after 1 week will need to redose
   - while had a CHADS score of 3, hold anticoagulation in the setting of
   active bleed.
   .
   # Hyperglycemia
   He was started on insulin during his hospitalization at [**Hospital3 1011**] and was continued on insulin during his hospitalization at
   [**Hospital1 5**]. [**Month (only) 8**] be the result of pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis
   vs. a new diagnosis of DM.
   - cont HISS
   - adjust insulin in TPN
   .
   # Hepatic Cirrhosis
   Imaging from abdominal CT and MRCP revealed hepatic cirrhosis, although
   patient has no history of this in the past. The hepatology team was
   consulted, and the felt no evidence of hepatic cirrhosis.  They
   recommended a liver biopsy, but overall felt that ascites more
   secondary to pancreatitis.  Hepatitis serologies were sent and were
   unremarkable.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history, including pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, intra-abdominal fluid collections, and a GDA pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, which required IR-guided embolization. He has been admitted to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His vital signs include a temperature of 38.2Â°C, heart rate of 97 bpm, and blood pressure of 138/49 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: He has atrial fibrillation, which was diagnosed at the OSH and was initially treated with diltiazem, which was later transitioned to amiodarone. His amiodarone was discontinued, but it is currently ordered.
* Renal: He has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.2 and a urine output of 986 mL. He is receiving furosemide (Lasix) and is being considered for continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
* Neurological: He is unresponsive, with a preliminary EEG showing encephalopathy. He has been off sedation for 24 hours and is being monitored for signs of withdrawal.
* Gastrointestinal: He has pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, and intra-abdominal fluid collections. He has been experiencing abdominal distention, which may be due to fluid overload.
* Dermatological: He has a diffuse, confluent maculopapular rash, which is thought to be drug-induced, possibly due to antibiotics.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Complete Blood Count (CBC): 24.7 K/uL
* Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN): 112 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
* Glucose: 157 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na+ 19 mEq/L, K+ 5.1 mEq/L, Cl- 98 mg/dL
* Liver function tests: Alkaline phosphatase 116 IU/L, Alanine transaminase (ALT) 10-30 IU/L, Aspartate transaminase (AST) 10-30 IU/L
* Lipase: 116 IU/L

The patient's medical complications include:

* Acute Renal Failure
* Unresponsiveness
* Pancreatitis
* Pancreatic Pseudocysts
* Intra-abdominal fluid collections
* Abdominal Rash
* Clostridium difficile infection
* Atrial Fibrillation
* Hyperglycemia
* Hepatic Cirrhosis

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Sepsis
* Multi-organ failure
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Pancreatic abscess
* Infected pancreatic pseudocysts
* Clostridium difficile colitis
* Electrolyte imbalances
* Hyperkalemia
* Hypokalemia
* Metabolic acidosis

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continued mechanical ventilation
* Antibiotics for pancreatitis and intra-abdominal infections
* Furosemide (Lasix) for fluid overload
* CRRT for acute renal failure
* Insulin for hyperglycemia
* Amiodarone for atrial fibrillation
* Antacids for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer
* Monitoring for signs of withdrawal and encephalopathy

The patient's family has been informed of his condition and is amenable to CRRT and other interventions. The patient's code status is full code.

   83 y/o male with history of BPH was transferred from an OSH for
   evaluation of pancreatitis. Evaluation was notable for large pancreatic
   pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections thought
   related to his pseudocyst. His course is complicated by GDA
   pseudoaneurysm hemorrhage into a pseudocyst, requiring IR guided
   embolization.
   .
   # Acute Renal Failure
   During his admission at the OSH, his creatinine was as high as 1.9 and
   then remained stable between .[**8-31**].  Creatinine started trending up in
   the last 48hrs, and was given one dose of lasix on the floor, with Cr
   rise to 1.2.  He was given mucomyst and NaHCO3 with the anticipation of
   contrast from IR procedure.  Given that patient was pulseless for 10
   minutes, potential for ATN.  Urine lytes consistent with intrarenal
   process, Eos negative but their NPV is ~ 16%.  Worsening today,
   uptrending daily.
   - UOP improved today on lasix, but Cr still rising, worsening
   hyponatremia
   - monitor lytes [**Hospital1 **]; trend Cr
   - avoid nephrotoxic meds
   - per prior discussion, family amenable to CRRT
 reconfirm
   - f/u renal recs re: when to start CRRT (goals of care)
   - check pm lytes
   .
   # Unresponsiveness S/p PEA arrest:  Unclear precipitant.  No
   hypoglycemia on the scene, and no e/o hypo/hyperkalemia.  Cardiac
   enzymes and CTA chest were negative.  The patient was noted to be
   hypoxic leading up to the event.  Still unresponsive after
   discontinuation of midazolam for sedation.  DDx includes sedation
   (impaired renal clearance), uremia, structural defect (i.e. stroke),
   seizure, metabolic (i.e. hyponatremia).
   - f/u EEG resuls to r/o epileptiform activity --> prelim is
   encephalopathy
   - hold on head imaging for now
   - continue to reassess mental status s/p withdrawal of midazolam this
   AM
   .

   Collections: On ERCP, patient was found to have bile duct filling
   defect, suggestive of external compression. He underwent follow-up EUS
   which revealed a large pancreatic pseudocyst. CTA Pancreas was also
   performed, which confirmed the large pseudocysts but also noted

   time.  Now s/p IR-guided embolization of GDA pseudoaneurysm, which

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a complex medical history, including a history of BPH, and has developed multiple complications, including:

* Pancreatitis with pseudocyst formation and associated intra-abdominal fluid collections
* Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
* Renal failure with worsening creatinine and hyponatremia
* Atrial fibrillation with a CHADS score of 3
* Hyperglycemia requiring insulin therapy
* Hepatic cirrhosis, although the patient has no prior history of this condition
* Clostridium difficile infection
* Abdominal rash, thought to be drug-induced
* Unresponsiveness following a pulseless electrical activity (PEA) arrest

The patient has undergone various interventions, including IR-guided embolization of a GDA pseudoaneurysm and has been treated with multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin and meropenem. He is currently receiving TPN and has been started on aztreonam and ciprofloxacin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine is rising, and he is at risk for further deterioration in renal function.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require further escalation of mechanical ventilation.
3. Infection: The patient has multiple infections, including C. difficile and a potential abdominal source of infection.
4. Hypoglycemia: The patient's hyperglycemia may require further management, including adjustments to insulin therapy.
5. Hepatic Cirrhosis: The patient's liver function may be compromised, and he may be at risk for further liver damage.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may require further management, including anticoagulation therapy.
7. Abdominal Rash: The patient's abdominal rash may be a sign of a systemic reaction, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and optimal treatment.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust therapy as needed.
2. Continue to provide mechanical ventilation and adjust therapy as needed.
3. Continue to treat the patient's infections, including C. difficile and any potential abdominal source of infection.
4. Adjust insulin therapy as needed to manage hyperglycemia.
5. Continue to evaluate and manage the patient's atrial fibrillation.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal rash and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Consider a goals of care discussion with the family to determine the optimal course of treatment for the patient.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male who was transferred from an outside hospital (OSH) for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a complex medical history, including atrial fibrillation, hyperglycemia, and hepatic cirrhosis.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has been rising, and he has been given lasix to try to improve urine output. His urine lytes are consistent with an intrarenal process, and he is at risk for ATN.
2. Unresponsiveness: The patient became unresponsive after a PEA arrest, and his EEG results show encephalopathic activity. The differential diagnosis includes sedation, uremia, structural defect, seizure, and metabolic disorders.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocysts, and intra-abdominal fluid collections. He has undergone ERCP, EUS, and CTA pancreas, and his general surgery team has recommended continued NPO and TPN with repeat imaging and clinic follow-up in 5-6 weeks.
4. Abdominal Rash: The patient has an ongoing abdominal rash that is thought to be drug-induced, possibly related to antibiotics.
5. Clostridium difficile infection: The patient was positive for C. diff and was started on flagyl, but he has developed worsening abdominal distention.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation and was started on amiodarone, which was discontinued, but is currently ordered again.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, which may be related to pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis or a new diagnosis of DM.
8. Hepatic Cirrhosis: The patient has hepatic cirrhosis, which was diagnosed on imaging, although he has no prior history of this condition.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Worsening renal failure, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Progression of pancreatitis, leading to further abdominal distension and potential complications such as sepsis or bowel obstruction.
3. Continued spread of the abdominal rash, leading to further complications such as sepsis or organ failure.
4. Development of sepsis or organ failure due to C. diff infection.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias or complications related to atrial fibrillation.
6. Further worsening of hyperglycemia, leading to potential complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis.
7. Further progression of hepatic cirrhosis, leading to potential complications such as ascites, encephalopathy, or liver failure.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his various conditions to prevent potential complications and optimize his care.

Summary:

The patient is an 83-year-old male who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital for evaluation of pancreatitis. He has a history of BPH and was diagnosed with pancreatitis, pancreatic pseudocyst, and intra-abdominal fluid collections. He underwent IR-guided embolization of a GDA pseudoaneurysm, which appeared to have hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst. The patient's course is complicated by acute renal failure, unresponsiveness, and multiple organ dysfunction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine is increasing, and he is at risk for further renal damage. Close monitoring of his creatinine and electrolytes is necessary.
2. Unresponsiveness: The patient's unresponsiveness is a concern, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause. EEG results show encephalopathy, and head imaging is pending.
3. Pancreatitis and Pancreatic Pseudocysts: The patient's pancreatitis and pseudocysts are causing abdominal distension and fluid overload. Monitoring of his abdominal distension and fluid status is necessary.
4. Intra-abdominal Fluid Collections: The patient has multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections, which are causing abdominal distension and fluid overload. Monitoring of his fluid status and abdominal distension is necessary.
5. Clostridium difficile Infection: The patient has a history of Clostridium difficile infection, and further evaluation and treatment are necessary to manage this infection.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and his amiodarone was discontinued. Monitoring of his heart rhythm and rate control is necessary.
7. Hyperglycemia: The patient has hyperglycemia, and further evaluation and treatment are necessary to manage this condition.
8. Hepatic Cirrhosis: The patient has hepatic cirrhosis, and further evaluation and treatment are necessary to manage this condition.
9. Abdominal Rash: The patient has an abdominal rash, which is thought to be drug-induced. Further evaluation and treatment are necessary to manage this condition.
10. Potential for ATN: The patient's pulseless episode and potential for ATN are concerns, and close monitoring of his renal function is necessary.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's creatinine and electrolytes closely.
2. Continue to evaluate the patient's unresponsiveness and determine the cause.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's abdominal distension and fluid status.
4. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's Clostridium difficile infection.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's heart rhythm and rate control.
6. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's hyperglycemia.
7. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's hepatic cirrhosis.
8. Continue to evaluate and treat the patient's abdominal rash.
9. Consider starting CRRT if the patient's renal function continues to decline.
10. Consider consulting with a nephrologist or hepatologist for further evaluation and treatment of the patient's renal and hepatic dysfunction.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and he has a history of ARF during his previous hospitalization. The patient's urine lytes are consistent with an intrarenal process, and his eosinophil count is negative, but the negative predictive value (NPV) is only 16%. The patient's family is amenable to continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
2. Unresponsiveness: The patient remains unresponsive, and the differential diagnosis includes sedation, uremia, structural defect, seizure, and metabolic disorders such as hyponatremia. An EEG was performed, which showed encephalopathic results.
3. Pancreatitis, Pancreatic Pseudocysts, and Intra-abdominal Fluid Collections: The patient has a large pancreatic pseudocyst with multiple intra-abdominal fluid collections, which is causing abdominal distension and discomfort. The patient has undergone IR-guided embolization of the GDA pseudoaneurysm, which appeared to have hemorrhaged into a pseudocyst.
4. Clostridium difficile Infection (CDI): The patient developed CDI within 48 hours of admission, which was treated with flagyl. However, the patient's abdominal distension may be due to massive fluid overload or other causes.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which was diagnosed during his previous hospitalization. He was started on amiodarone, but it was discontinued, and now he is being redosed due to the inability to administer PO meds.
6. Hyperglycemia: The patient was started on insulin during his previous hospitalization and was continued on insulin during his current hospitalization. The patient's hyperglycemia may be due to pancreatic insufficiency with pancreatitis or a new diagnosis of diabetes mellitus.
7. Hepatic Cirrhosis: The patient has imaging evidence of hepatic cirrhosis, although he has no history of this in the past. The patient's family is amenable to a liver biopsy, but the hepatology team feels that ascites is more likely secondary to pancreatitis.
